params.text:
Maturity index is a sign or indication of the readiness of the crop to be harvested. Physiological maturity is when green mature fruits undergo normal ripening of after harvesting. Commercial or horticultural maturity is harvesting of the produce based on the type of maturity as preferred by the consumers. 

          For bitter gourd, commercial or horticultural maturity is used as its maturity index.

Harvesting normally starts at 15-20 days after fruit set or 90 days after planting. 

  • Harvest the marketable fruits frequently to avoid over size and over maturity. But harvest the fruits at earlier stage depending on the purpose or the consumer’s/market preference.

  • At the field level, pre-sort and place the harvest fruits under shade areas to avoid direct exposure from the sun.

  • For planting material, harvest the ripe fruits or yellow to yellow orange in color and no disease and insect damage.

In post-harvest handling, the following are recommended: 

  • Sort the fruits depending on the purpose for which they will be used. 

  • Separate the marketable and unmarketable fruits to avoid too low price of the produce. 

  • Pack the marketable fruits in a polyethylene bag or any available package container that fits to the fruits. 

Use lining or cushion material if the package container has rough edges and sides to avoid damage.
